title: A Prediction Model of Hot Spot Temperature for Split-Windings Traction Transformer Considering the Load Characteristics

authors.name: Wei Zhang
affiliations: Guizhou Electric Power Design and Research Institute

authors.name: Shuo Liang
affiliations: Guizhou Electric Power Design and Research Institute

abstract: Hot spot temperature (HST) is an important parameter reflecting the working state of the traction transformer, and the load characteristics have a great influence on the HST. The current researches rarely consider the load characteristics of transformers in-depth, and most of the research on the temperature field focuses on steady load. Therefore, a prediction model of HST for the traction transformer considering the load characteristics is established by the finite element simulation in this paper. Considering the impact and nonlinearity of traction load, the influence of the load characteristics on the HST is studied. Analysis of the load curve revealed that the steady and step load combination could well simulate the traction load. Based on the analysis of traction transformer load characteristics, the temperature field coupling calculation of traction transformer is carried out according to the VI normative duty class. On this basis, the influence of load rate and time on HST is studied. The present findings show that the method can predict the HST of traction transformer under different working conditions and provide a reference for load dispatching of traction transformer. The simulation data are in good agreement with the test results, and the average relative error is 3.4%. The results verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

A Prediction Model of Hot Spot Temperature
for Split-Windings Traction Transformer
Considering the Load Characteristics
YIYI ZHANG

ABSTRACT Hot spot temperature (HST) is an important parameter reﬂecting the working state of the
traction transformer, and the load characteristics have a great inﬂuence on the HST. The current researches
rarely consider the load characteristics of transformers in-depth, and most of the research on the temperature
ﬁeld focuses on steady load. Therefore, a prediction model of HST for the traction transformer considering
the load characteristics is established by the ﬁnite element simulation in this paper. Considering the impact
and nonlinearity of traction load, the inﬂuence of the load characteristics on the HST is studied. Analysis
of the load curve revealed that the steady and step load combination could well simulate the traction load.
Based on the analysis of traction transformer load characteristics, the temperature ﬁeld coupling calculation
of traction transformer is carried out according to the VI normative duty class. On this basis, the inﬂuence
of load rate and time on HST is studied. The present ﬁndings show that the method can predict the HST
of traction transformer under different working conditions and provide a reference for load dispatching of
traction transformer. The simulation data are in good agreement with the test results, and the average relative
error is 3.4%. The results verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.
INDEX TERMSTraction transformers, hot spot temperature, load characteristics, temperature ﬁeld analysis,
ﬁnite element simulation.
I. INTRODUCTION
As an essential part of urban rail transit, the traction
transformer operation’s reliability depends on its insula-
tion performance [1], [2]. The traction transformer’s insu-
lation performance is closely related to the heat generation
and heat dissipation inside the traction transformer [3], [4].
The traction transformer’s operation instability or damage is
mainly due to the temperature of the transformer windings
The associate editor coordinating the review of this manuscript and
approving it for publication was Hui Ma
.
exceeding the insulating material limit’s thermal resistance.
Therefore, the accurate prediction of HST for traction trans-
former is of great signiﬁcance to improve the traction trans-
former operation’s reliability and ensure the train’s stable
operation [5], [6].
The research of oil-paper insulation of the transformer has
received extensive attention [7]–[9], and the aging mecha-
nism of oil-paper insulation have been fully studied. Insu-
lation aging is closely related to the internal temperature
ﬁeld of the transformer. The measurement and calculation of
the transformer’s internal temperature ﬁeld have been a hot
VOLUME 9, 2021 This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 License. For more information, see https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ 22605
Y. Zhanget al.: Prediction Model of Hot Spot Temperature for Split-Windings Traction Transformer Considering the Load Characteristics
topic for many scholars. The existing research on the trans-
former temperature ﬁeld is mainly divided into three meth-
ods: direct measurement method, thermal circuit method,
and the numerical analysis method. The direct measurement
method directly measures HST through ﬁber optic tem-
perature sensors installed inside the transformer. However,
the cost of ﬁber optic instruments is relatively high and is not
suitable for large-scale applications. Besides, the presence of
ﬁber optic instruments will affect the heat dissipation inside
the transformer. Considered the similarity between electrical
and heat-transfer phenomena, the thermal circuit method is
often used to calculate the HST of the transformer. However,
the key parameters, such as thermal capacity and resistance
in the thermal circuit are challenging to obtain.
In recent years, with the development of numerical cal-
culation technology, the research on the internal tempera-
ture ﬁeld by the numerical analysis method has gradually
increased [10]–[12]. D. Kweon measured the HST of the
transformer, which was ﬁlled with mineral oil and natural
ester liquid, respectively, with optical ﬁber sensors [13].
Based on the ﬂow heat ﬁeld calculation, Y. Deng combined
support vector regression to predict the HST of the trans-
former [14]. T. Dao and B. T. Phung used the COMSOL
simulation software to solve the heat equation and the free
convection equation and studied the temperature rise inside
the oil-immersed transformer [15]. C. Liu established two
accurate two-dimensional models to calculate the windings’
energy loss and studied the temperature ﬁeld of the dry-type
transformer by combining indirect coupling and sequential
coupling [16]. Most scholars’ research on the temperature
ﬁeld focuses on load rating or small load ﬂuctuation, which
is not suitable for dynamic load changes.
The operating environment of the traction transformer is
quite complicated. When the train passes through the power
supply interval at high speed or with a heavy load, the traction
transformer is overloaded. The temperature of the windings
rises sharply. The traction transformer restores the aver-
age load after the train passes. Due to the traction load’s
particularity, the traction transformer internal temperature
ﬁeld variation law is different from the power transformer.
Thus, insulation aging is also different from that of the
power transformer [17], [18]. Based on the equivalent thermal
circuit [19], [20] and the parameter optimized equivalent
thermal circuit [21]–[23], many scholars have discussed the
transformer modeling problem considering load characteris-
tics. In the transformer temperature ﬁeld research using the
numerical analysis method, the transformer’s load character-
istics are rarely considered. It is necessary to further study the
temperature ﬁeld of traction transformer under dynamic load
changes.
In view of the above issues, the prediction model of HST
for traction transformer is established in this paper. The ﬂow
chart of 3D coupled Fluid-Solid-Thermal analysis is shown
in Fig. 1. The present ﬁndings of urban rail transit load
show that the traction transformer’s load variation can be
well simulated by combining steady load with step load.
FIGURE 1. Flow chart of 3D coupled fluid-solid-thermal analysis.
Based on the actual loss of traction transformer, according
to the theory of heat transfer and ﬂuid mechanics, the tem-
perature ﬁeld coupling calculation is carried out according
to the VI normative duty class. On this basis, the traction
transformer’s temperature ﬁeld under the different load rates
is calculated according to different working conditions of the
traction transformer. The transformer temperature rise test
veriﬁes the effectiveness of the proposed method. The anal-
ysis method can predict the HST of the traction transformer
under different working conditions and provide a reference
for operation scheduling and ﬁxed-point monitoring of the
traction transformer.
II. ANALYSIS METHOD
A. HEAT GENERATION ANALYSIS
1) LOSS ANALYSIS UNDER RATED LOAD
During the traction transformer operation, the iron core,
windings, and other iron components will all suffer losses
due to the existence of resistance and reluctance. These losses
are converted into heat, part of which is dissipated into the
surrounding air, the other part increases the components’ tem-
perature. The increase in temperature will further enlarge the
loss. The internal heating of the traction transformer mainly
comes from loss [24], [25], and the expressions of loss are as
follows:
PT =PNL +PLL (1)


PNL =Phl +Pcl
Phl =ηf B 1.6
maxV ×10−3
Pcl =ηd2f 2B2
maxV ×10−3
(2)
where, PT is the total loss of the traction transformer,
PNL is no-load loss, PLL is load loss, Phl is magnetic hys-
teresis loss, Pcl is eddy-current loss, ηis the hysteresis factor
of the iron core, f is the power supply frequency, Bmax is the
22606 VOLUME 9, 2021
Y. Zhanget al.: Prediction Model of Hot Spot Temperature for Split-Windings Traction Transformer Considering the Load Characteristics
maximum ﬂux density, V is the volume of the iron core, d is
the thickness of silicon steel sheet.
In the load loss, the DC loss of windings accounts for the
majority. The stray loss of other iron structures includes the
transformer bracket, transformer shell, yoke, only accounts
for a small proportion, and can be ignored. In practical cal-
culation, it is considered that the DC loss is equal to the load
loss. The expression of load loss is as follows:
PLL =I2
HN rHN,75◦C +I2
LN rLN,75◦C (3)
where, IHN (ILN ) is the rated current of the HV (LV) windings,
rHN,75◦C (rLN,75◦C ) is the total resistance of the HV (LV)
windings when converted to 75 ◦C.
There are three heat sources in the operation of traction
transformer: the heat converted by core loss, the heat con-
verted by internal loss of the LV windings, and the heat
converted by internal loss of the HV windings [26]. The heat
generated by the dielectric loss of the traction transformer’s
insulation material is ignored in this paper because the mag-
nitude of the loss is relatively small [27]. The no-load loss
of traction transformer is little affected by temperature and
is set as a constant heat source. Most of the load loss is
DC loss, which is positively correlated with temperature and
proportional to the load rate’s square. The resistivity of the
metal at temperature t is as follows [28]:
ρ=ρ0(1 +αt) (4)
where, ρ0 is the resistivity of the metal at 0 ◦C, αis the temper-
ature coefﬁcient of the metal. In this paper, the temperature
coefﬁcient of copper is 0.00393.
The loss of the HV and LV windings at temperature t is as
follows, respectively [29]:
{
Pf =Ph ·[1 +α·(t −t0)]
PS =Pl ·[1 +α·(t −t0)] (5)
where, Ph and Pl are the loss of the HV and LV windings at
t0, t is the temperature of the windings, t0 is 75◦C.
2) LOSS ANALYSIS UNDER STEP LOAD
In practical application, it is not easy to calculate with an
accurate load curve. For the steady load transformer and
the steady load transformer with a superimposed step load,
the load cycle curve is represented by a constant current
value or working system level within the speciﬁed duration.
IEC 146-1-1 (1991) [30] gives six normative duty classes.
The deﬁnition of VI normative duty class is showed as 1.0p.u.
continuous, 1.5p.u.2h, 3.0p.u. 1min. The cyclic load curve of
the VI normative duty class is shown in Fig. 2.
The repeated cyclic load is equivalently converted into a
steady load through the root mean square calculation. The
calculation is divided into two stages, and the calculation

This conversion method is also applicable to other working

TABLE 1. Root mean square value of the load cycle curve.
where, Pi is the equivalent steady load converted, tj is the

(Id ) in the load cycle.
The functional schematic diagram of the traction station
is shown in Fig. 3. In typical operation, a traction station is
responsible for providing power for the station and the two
adjacent stations in the up and down direction, with a load
root value of 1.0p.U. and a possible maximum peak load
of 1.76p.U. with a duration of less than 0.5 min. Suppose
a traction station (station B) exits operation due to fault
or maintenance within a certain period. The two adjacent
traction stations (station A and station C) need to bear 50%
of the faulty station’s load. The maximum bearing time is
2 hours. Currently, each station’s square root value is about
1.5p.U., and the possible maximum peak load is 2.64p.U.
FIGURE 3. Functional diagram of traction station.

traction transformer is simulated and analyzed under the

and LV windings at load rate k is as follows, respectively:

The iron core, LV windings, and HV windings are treated
as uniform heating bodies. The heat generation rate can be
expressed as follows:
Q =P/Ve (8)
where, Q is the heating generation rate of the iron core
(windings), P is the loss of the iron core (windings), and Ve is

Through the above analysis of the traction transformer loss,
the simulation model’s load data are obtained. The core loss
data is calculated by equation (2), and the windings loss data
is calculated by equation (3) and equation (7). The calculation
results are presented in Table 2.
TABLE 2. Load data of the traction transformer.
B. HEAT DISSIPATION ANALYSIS
The heat dissipation methods of the traction transformer
include heat conduction, convection, and radiation. The heat
transfer inside the windings, the iron core, and the insulating
resin mainly depend on heat conduction. The surface of the
iron core, LV and HV windings are in contact with air, and
the heat is transferred through convection. Moreover, the iron
core, LV and HV windings, and the surrounding environment
interact through radiation.
In the simulation of convection problems, it is critical to
determine whether the ﬂow is laminar or turbulence. Four
evaluation indicators are proposed to determine the gas ﬂow
type: Reynolds number, Grashof number, Rayleigh number,
and Prandtl number. Rayleigh number is used for evaluation
in this paper, and its expression is as follows [31]:
Ra =gαp1Th3
κν (9)
where, g is the gravitational acceleration, αp is the thermal
expansion coefﬁcient of air, 1T is the temperature difference,
h is the height of the convective object, k is the thermal
diffusion coefﬁcient of air, νis the kinematic viscosity.
The simulation and test are carried out in an environ-
ment of 30 ◦C. After calculation, the Rayleigh number is less
than 1 ·109;the simulation model’s airﬂow state is laminar.
C. CONTROL EQUATIONS
In the Fluid-Solid-Thermal coupling model, the ﬂow of air
is obtained by the Navier-Stokes ﬂuid equation, the ﬂuid
heat transfer control equation and solid heat transfer control
equation are used for the ﬁnite element calculation of temper-
ature distribution. The heat source in the heat transfer control
equation comes from the loss of heating during the traction
transformer operation.
Applying the Navier-Stokes ﬂuid equation to air, the con-
trol equation is as follows:

where, ρ is the density of the ﬂuid, u is a velocity vector of
the ﬂuid, I is the identity matrix, µis the power viscosity,
T is the temperature of the ﬂuid, F is the volume force
(general default is 0).
Applying the heat transfer physics to all areas, the control
equation is as follows:

where, Cp is the solid constant pressure heat capacity, Cp1 is
the ﬂuid constant pressure heat capacity, q is the local heat
ﬂux density, k is the thermal conductivity.
III. ESTABLISHMENT OF SIMULATION MODEL
A. THE ESTABLISHED 3D GEOMETRIC MODEL
This paper takes a step-down transformer of 35kV traction
station as the prototype, model ZQSC-L-2500/35, insulation
class F, as shown in Fig. 4. There are air channels between
the iron core, LV and HV windings. Both the LV and HV
windings are designed to be split into inner and outer layers to
enhance heat dissipation. The basic parameters of the traction
transformer are shown in Table 3.
TABLE 3. Basic parameters of the traction transformer.
22608 VOLUME 9, 2021
Y. Zhanget al.: Prediction Model of Hot Spot Temperature for Split-Windings Traction Transformer Considering the Load Characteristics
FIGURE 4. ZQSC-L-2500/35 traction transformer.
According to the actual structure of the traction trans-
former, the corresponding three-dimensional numerical cal-
culation model is established. The structure of the traction
transformer is quite complicated. In order to reduce the
amount of calculation, the structure of the traction trans-
former is simpliﬁed as follows:
1) The actual iron core is made of silicon steel sheets, and
its cross-section is approximately circular. In order to reduce
the amount of calculation, the iron core is smoothed.
2) There is a layer of turn-insulating between each turn
of windings. Because the insulation is very thin, it has little
inﬂuence on the heat dissipation of the windings. In this
study, the turn-insulating is ignored.
3) To simplify the calculation, the clamps, brackets, and
insulating tubes of the traction transformer are ignored.
B. THE INITIAL VALUE AND BOUNDARY CONDITIONS OF
SIMULATION
According to the traction transformer’s operating environ-
ment and heat dissipation conditions, the reasonable initial
value and boundary conditions are set up.
1) The on-site traction transformer is installed indoors.
The ambient temperature is set at 30 ◦C. Set the material
parameters separately according to the speciﬁc materials used
in each part of the actual traction transformer. The parameter
settings are shown in Table 4.
2) Fluid ﬁeld boundary conditions [32]. The traction trans-
former is installed in the cabinet during actual operation. The
cold air enters from the bottom, and the hot air ﬂows out from
the top of the cabinet under natural convection. The initial
ambient wind speed is set as a breeze, which is 0.1m/s.
3) Heat transfer boundary conditions. The solid heat trans-
fer physics is used in all areas except the air area. The
initial temperature is determined by each part of the traction
transformer’s temperature at the beginning of the temperature
rise test. The air area uses ﬂuid heat transfer physics. The
convective heat ﬂux is applied to the air region to simulate
the cooling effect of air. The convective heat ﬂux can be
expressed as follows:
q =h ·(Text −T ) (12)
TABLE 4. Material parameters setting.
where, q is heat ﬂux, h is the heat transfer coefﬁcient, Text is
the external temperature, T is the temperature of the ﬂuid.
C. MESHING
The grid division directly affects the calculation accuracy and
the amount of calculation. In order to reduce the amount of
computation under the premise of ensuring the calculation
accuracy, the principle of reﬁning the grid of critical com-
ponents is adopted. The LV and HV windings’ grid size is set
to be more reﬁned, and the grid size of the iron core and air
area is set to be coarser. The traction transformer’s geometric
model meshes with a free tetrahedral network, and skewness
is used to measure the simulation model’s grid quality. The
mesh model shown in Fig. 5 can be obtained. The closer the
value is to 1, the higher the mesh quality is. In general, a value
of less than 0.1 is not allowed. After grid division, the average
element quality is 0.5858, and the number of elements of the
simulation model is 552558. The geometric parameters of the
traction transformer’s windings and iron core of the traction
transformer are shown in Table 5 and Table 6.
FIGURE 5. Quality diagram of grid division for the traction transformer.
TABLE 5. Geometric parameters of the traction transformer windings.

TABLE 6. Geometric parameters of the traction transformer core.
IV. SIMULATION RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
A. ANALYSIS OF SIMULATION RESULTS UNDER RATED
LOAD
This simulation object is a dry-type transformer used in the
traction station. The simulation calculation is based on the
actual traction transformer, which is convenient compared
to the temperature rise test’s value. First, the traction trans-
former’s temperature ﬁeld is calculated under the rated load,
and the simulation results are shown in Fig. 6.
FIGURE 6. The temperature distribution of (a) Overall traction
transformer, (b) Iron core, (c) LV windings, (d) HV windings.
As shown in Fig. 6, the traction transformer’s temperature
ﬁeld distribution is low-high-low from the bottom to the top.
The outer layer of HV windings is located at the outermost
layer of the traction transformer. It has the right heat dis-
sipation conditions, and the temperature distribution law is
not as apparent as the inner layer. Comparing Fig. 6 (c) with
Fig. 6 (d), the heat dissipation condition of the outer layer
of HV windings is better than that of the inner layer. The
overall temperature distribution of the inner layer is higher
than that of the outer layer. The heat dissipation condition
of the LV windings’ outer layer is also better than that of the
inner layer. However, the loss of the outer layer is much larger
than the inner layer due to the traction transformer’s design,
which results in a higher overall temperature distribution of
the outer layer of LV windings.
The hot spot is the key point of the research on the tem-
perature ﬁeld of the traction transformer. This paper takes
the outer layer of LV windings and the inner layer of HV
windings as the primary research objects (in the following,
LV windings speciﬁcally refer to the outer layer of LV wind-
ings, and HV windings speciﬁcally refer to the inner layer of
HV windings). The temperature rises process of the LV and
HV windings under the rated load is shown in Fig. 7.
FIGURE 7. Longitudinal temperature rise process of (a) LV windings,
(b) HV windings.
As shown in Fig. 7, the longitudinal temperature distribu-
tion curve shows a low-high-low parabola distribution due to
the inﬂuence of wall viscosity. In the ﬁgure, the abscissa is
the longitudinal height of the LV and HV windings. The tem-
perature increases with height and then gradually decreases
after reaching the maximum. The temperature rises speed is
fast at the beginning of the simulation. With the increase of
time, the rising speed of temperature slows down. Finally,
the temperature ﬁeld tends to be stable. The reason is that
the thermal convection is not fully formed at the begin-
ning. The internal heat transfer of the traction transformer
is mainly through heat conduction and radiation, and heat
dissipation is not apparent; with the increase of working time,
the effect of convective heat dissipation gradually increases.
Finally, the balance of heat generation and heat dissipation is
achieved, the traction transformer’s temperature ﬁeld tends to
be stable. In the process of temperature rise, the location of
HST remains unchanged.
After the temperature ﬁeld is stable, the LV and HV wind-
ings’ temperature distribution is shown in Fig. 8. The HST of
LV windings is 82 ◦C, located at about 72% of the height of
22610 VOLUME 9, 2021
Y. Zhanget al.: Prediction Model of Hot Spot Temperature for Split-Windings Traction Transformer Considering the Load Characteristics
FIGURE 8. Longitudinal temperature curve of LV windings and HV
windings under rated load.
LV windings; the HST of HV windings is 98 ◦C, located at
about 70% of the height of HV windings.
B. ANALYSIS OF SIMULATION RESULTS UNDER STEP
LOAD
The traction transformer’s actual operating environment is
quite complex, and the traction transformer is often in the
state of short-time overload. Due to the particularity of trac-
tion load, in order to obtain the accurate distribution of tem-
perature ﬁeld, the step load is added for further study based
on steady load according to the requirements of VI normative
duty class. The hot spots of the LV and HV windings are taken
as the research node. The temperature rise process of HST is
studied, as shown in Fig. 9.
As shown in Fig. 9, the step load is applied after the temper-
ature ﬁeld of the traction transformer reaches a steady state.
The temperature increased rapidly, and cannot reach a steady
state at the end of the test. The reason is that the internal
heat source increases instantaneously as the load changes, and
the increase in heat dissipation cannot keep up with the heat
generation. At the end of the simulation calculation, the LV
and HV windings’ longitudinal temperature distribution is
shown in Fig. 10.
As shown in Fig. 10, the trend of longitudinal temperature
distribution is consistent with the steady temperature ﬁeld,
and the curve of longitudinal temperature distribution is a
parabola of low-high-low. The location of the hot spots in the
LV windings and the HV windings is almost unchanged, and
the temperature of the hot spots has changed. The HST of
LV windings is 131 ◦C, located at about 70% of the height of
LV windings; the HST of HV windings is 161 ◦C, located at
about 70% of the height of HV windings.
C. INFLUENCE OF STEP LOAD WITH DIFFERENT LOAD
RATES
The traction transformer will encounter different working
conditions in actual operation. There are different require-
ments for their load capacity under different working con-
ditions. Different working conditions can be represented by
different combinations of steady load and step load. In order
FIGURE 9. The temperature rise process of (a) LV windings hot spot,
(b) HV windings hot spot.
FIGURE 10. Longitudinal temperature curve of LV windings and HV
windings under step load.
to obtain the HST of the traction transformer under different
working conditions, it is necessary to calculate the temper-
ature ﬁeld of the traction transformer under different load
rates. Apply 100% rated load to the traction transformer,
and then apply step load at different load rates after the
traction transformer’s temperature ﬁeld is stable. The hot spot
location of the traction transformer is selected as the research
node. The ambient temperature is 30 ◦C, and the simulation
time of step load is 2 hours. This model takes a value every
0.2 h from the simulation time range (10 h-12 h) to study
the HST’s effects under different load rates. The simulation
results are shown in Fig. 11.
As shown in Fig. 11, the temperature rises rapidly with
the application of the step load. The higher the load rate,
the faster the temperature rises. The temperature rise of the
VOLUME 9, 2021 22611
Y. Zhanget al.: Prediction Model of Hot Spot Temperature for Split-Windings Traction Transformer Considering the Load Characteristics
FIGURE 11. Hot spot temperature change of the traction transformer
under different load rates.
FIGURE 12. The fitting curves of hot spot temperature change of the
traction transformer under different load rates.
traction transformer is approximately linear with simulation
time. In order to obtain the general functional relationship
between time and HST under different load rates, the ﬁtting
analysis is carried out to studied the variation law of HST vs.
simulation time under different load rates. The ﬁtting curves
are shown in Fig. 12, and the obtained ﬁtting equations are
tabulated in Table 7. These formulas can be used to study
the inﬂuence of different load rates on traction transformer
operation and provide a reference for load dispatch.
D. DISCUSSION
The traction transformer studied in this paper is the dry-type
transformer, insulation grade is F. The international standard
IEC 60076-11-2004 [33] speciﬁes the temperature rise limit
of a dry-type transformer. For dry-type transformer coil with
class F insulation material, the limit working temperature
is 155 ◦C, and the maximum temperature rise should be less
than 100k. According to the simulation results, the HST of
the traction transformer is 161 ◦C, and the maximum tem-
perature rise is 131k, which has greatly exceeded the limit
value of class F insulation. The HST directly affects the
performance of insulation materials. The insulation of the
traction transformer will be signiﬁcantly damaged under this
working temperature.
TABLE 7. The obtained fitting equations of hot spot temperature vs.
simulation time under different load rates.
In order to prolong the operating life of the traction trans-
former, it is necessary to adjust and control the traction
load reasonably. Set the critical temperature as 130 ◦C. The
time required for HST to reach the limit is different under
different load rates. The larger the load rate, the shorter the
time required for HST to reach the limit. The step load of
the VI normative duty class is 150% rated load. In order to
avoid or reduce the temperature overrun time, the following
suggestions are put forward:
1) If it is in peak operation, it is challenging to reduce train
frequency. According to the ﬁtting equation shown in Table 7,
the time required for HST to reach 130 ◦C is 0.81 hours.
In other words, in order to avoid damaging the traction
transformer’s insulation performance, the fault station should
be put into operation again within 0.81 hours to restore the
normal load of two heavy haul traction stations.
2) If the fault cannot be eliminated in a short time, the train
frequency must be reduced. According to the simulation
results in Fig. 11, the HST is below 130 ◦C when the traction
transformer’s load rate is less than 130% rated load. In other
words, it is necessary to reduce the train frequency to keep
the equivalent load rate below 130% rated load to ensure the
safe and stable operation of the train.
V. TEMPERATURE RISE TEST AND VERIFICATION
In order to verify the numerical calculation method’s accu-
racy, the temperature rise test is carried out by the simu-
lated load method. The temperature change of the iron core,
LV windings, and HV windings is measured by the temper-
ature sensor. The temperature rise of windings is determined
by the combination of the no-load test and the short-circuit
test. When the windings pass through the rated current and
the core is rated excitation, the temperature rise expression of
windings is shown as follows:
1θc∗=1θc
[
1 +(1θe/1θc)1/k
]k
(13)
where, 1θe is the windings temperature rise under no-load
test, 1θc is the windings temperature rise under short-circuit
22612 VOLUME 9, 2021
Y. Zhanget al.: Prediction Model of Hot Spot Temperature for Split-Windings Traction Transformer Considering the Load Characteristics
FIGURE 13. Schematic diagram of temperature rise test.
FIGURE 14. The comparison and relative error of measured values and
calculated curves. (a) Phase A, (b) Phase B, (c) Phase C.
test, k is the temperature coefﬁcient. For the self-cooling
transformer, k is taken as 0.8.
The temperature rise test is carried out following the
requirements of the power transformer test guide (IEC 60726-
1982) [34] and Part 11 dry-type transformer of the power
transformer (IEC 60076-11-2004). The schematic diagram of
the temperature rise test is shown in Fig. 13. In the tempera-
ture rise test, the iron core, HV windings, and LV windings of
three phases are set with measuring points, respectively. The
measuring points are placed at the hot spots of each part, and a
total of nine measuring points are set. The applied test current
is the rated current until the temperature ﬁeld is stable. When
the temperature rise is less than 1 ◦C per hour, it is considered
that the temperature ﬁeld tends to be stable. The temperature
at each measuring point is measured once an hour, and the
temperature rise test lasts for 9 hours.
According to equation (13), the measured values of each
measuring point can be obtained. The comparison of mea-
sured values of measuring points and calculated curves is
drawn in Fig. 14. Depending on the observation of the mea-
sured value and the calculated value in Fig. 14, the two values
are in good agreement within the test’s period except for
individual data points. In order to quantitatively analyze the
correlation between the calculated value and the measured
value, the relative error between the measured value and the
calculated value is calculated point by point using equation
(14). The calculation results are also presented in Fig. 14.
Re =|T ∗−T |
T ×100% (14)
where, Re is the relative error, T∗is the calculated temperature
value, T is the measured value.
After calculation, the maximum/minimum relative error is
6%/0.3%. The average values of relative error at measuring
points of three phases are 3.3%, 3.7%, and 3.2%. Thus, this
paper’s analysis method can simulate the actual operation
of the traction transformer, and calculate the distribution
and change of temperature ﬁeld of the traction transformer
accurately relatively.
VI. CONCLUSION
In this paper, the 2200kV A traction transformer is the research
object. A prediction model of HST is established based on
the solid ﬁeld, ﬂuid ﬁeld, and heat transfer ﬁeld. Through
the iterative calculation of the temperature ﬁeld, the traction
transformer’s temperature ﬁeld under VI normative duty class
is analyzed. On this basis, the inﬂuence of load factor and
time on the HST of traction transformer is studied. The
present ﬁndings can be concluded as follows:
1) In practical application, it is not easy to calculate with an
accurate load curve. By combining the steady load and step
load, the traction transformer’s load change can be well sim-
ulated. Different combinations of steady load and step load
can be used to predict the traction transformer’s temperature
ﬁeld under different working conditions.
2) The temperature rise test of the actual traction trans-
former is carried out. The maximum deviation between the
test data and the simulation data is 6%. The average relative
error is 3.4%, which is within the allowable error range of the
project. The analysis method of combining temperature rise
test with numerical simulation can effectively avoid the insu-
lation loss caused by the overload test of traction transformer.
3) The temperature ﬁeld of the traction transformer is
studied according to the VI normative duty class. The sim-
ulation results show that the HST of the traction transformer
is 98◦C at rated load, the HST is 161 ◦C at step load. The hot
spot is located at about 70% of the height of HV windings.
In order to avoid damage to the insulation performance of
VOLUME 9, 2021 22613
Y. Zhanget al.: Prediction Model of Hot Spot Temperature for Split-Windings Traction Transformer Considering the Load Characteristics
the traction transformer, it is necessary to take measures to
restore the heavy haul traction station to an average load
within 0.81 hours.
4) The load rate of the traction transformer signiﬁcantly
affects the HST of the traction transformer. The equations
of HST vs. simulation time under different load rates are
obtained. These equations can provide a reference for the
effect of load rate and time on the on-site traction transformer.
According to the HST equations, the operation load could be
adjusted reasonably to avoid or reduce the overload time of
the traction transformer and prolong traction transformer life.

YIYI ZHANG (Member, IEEE) was born in
Guangxi, China, in 1986. He received the bach-
elor’s degree in electrical engineering from
Guangxi University, Nanning, China, in 2008,
and the Ph.D. degree in electrical engineering
from Chongqing University, Chongqing, China,
in 2014. In 2014, he joined Guangxi University,
where he is currently an Associate Professor with
the College of Electrical Engineering. He is the
author and coauthor of over 50 articles published
in SCI journals. His current research interest includes the intelligent diagno-
sis for transformers.
